conclusion: Analyze v-t graphs for objects A and B from 0 to t1.
Displacement is given by the area under the v-t graph.
Area under the graph of object A represents its displacement.
Area under the graph of object B represents its displacement.
At t = 0, both objects start from the same point.
Observe areas under the curves of A and B as time progresses.
If area under curve A is always greater than B, displacement difference increases.
If areas are equal or B surpasses A, displacement difference does not continuously increase.
Initially, area under curve A is greater than B.
Curves intersect as time progresses towards t1.
Curves intersecting means displacement difference is zero at some point.
Difference in displacement is not continuously increasing over the interval.
Final answer: Displacement difference is not necessarily continuously increasing.
